body.section:
Note:
Faceted selection and faceted reference are used intertwined and refer to the exact same thing.
Faceted selection gives you the possibility to browse through your filtered hierarchical physical content (and virtual content, but we'll keep this for advanced content modelling). The filter is based on facets (metadata) on documents. An example would be, that you only want to show documents which are english and published. By creating some smart faceted selections, you can very easily create websites which are multilingual, and have a preview/live or any other state in between. Exposing your DMS with faceted selection and authorization (and even facet search combined!) gives you a lot of flexibility in exposing your (unstructured) physical content in many different (virtual) structured ways.
Suppose we have the same hierachical repository data as with the facet search, so:
Folder Type Size Age ------------------------------------------------------------------------ Pets |-- Dogs | |-- dog1 Dog Large Adult | |-- dog2 Dog Medium Adult | |-- dog3 Dog Small Young | `-- dog4 Dog Large Adult |-- Rabbits | |-- rabbit1 Rabbit Large Young | |-- rabbit2 Rabbit Large Old | |-- rabbit3 Rabbit Small Young `-- Horses |-- horse1 Horse Small Young |-- horse2 Horse Large Young `-- horse3 Horse Large Old
Now, suppose, I want to browse through the data, but a filter applied to only show large animals. This is realized by simply creating a facet select node that indicates to only show animals which are of size 'large'. Suppose that my facet select node is called 'IsLarge', then my navigation would look like:
Folder Type Size Age ------------------------------------------------------------------------ IsLarge `-- Pets |-- Dogs | |-- dog1 Dog Large Adult | `-- dog4 Dog Large Adult |-- Rabbits | |-- rabbit1 Rabbit Large Young | |-- rabbit2 Rabbit Large Old |-- Horses |-- horse2 Horse Large Young `-- horse3 Horse Large Old
I might also have a facet select node which filters such that I get 'large' and 'young' only. Then, my navigation would be
Folder Type Size Age ------------------------------------------------------------------------ IsLargeAndYoung `-- Pets |-- Rabbits | `-- rabbit1 Rabbit Large Young `-- Horses `-- horse2 Horse Large Young
Obviously you can have as many facet select nodes as you want. What we did not yet explain, is that you do not need to have the facet select starting filtering on the root node. You can also make a facet select node, that filters for only 'large' animals, and has starting point /Pets/Dogs. This would result in a navigation like:
Folder Type Size Age ------------------------------------------------------------------------ IsLarge |-- dog1 Dog Large Adult `-- dog4 Dog Large Adult
You can even have a facet select, which filters a hierarchical tree which contains in turn another facet select. So, you can have facet selects in facet selects. Instead of a facetselect in a facetselect, you can have a facetsearch node inside the result of a facetselect node! From this facetsearch node on, faceted navigation will be displayed.
By understanding the possibilities, you can model endless combinations of structured data resulting from unstructered data. Obviously, under water all documents are being checked wether the user is authorized to see the document.
Take a look at advanced content modelling to learn about possibilities and use cases. Note that you might want to look at it twice because it is not trivial. In the end, understanding modelling of data on unstructured data will give you an enormeous freedom and enables you developing complex frontend websites or expose a DMS without writing code.
